instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PUBS_G3H: What is PUBS_G3H? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PUBS_G3H, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that has no power, originally customer said it was working and suddenly stopped after a restart, no liquid else than a bit on the ssd connector, put it through the ultra sonic and seems clean. <SIGNAL>PUBS_G3H</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground with less than 1ohm to ground and shorted to <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL> with around 5ohms. would this be a dead cpu. Tried injecting voltage on ppbus and nothing got warm.

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
STOP to inject into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in this manner!!!

Check first if any high-side MOSFET is shorted.
If you have 1 ohm at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 5 ohm at <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL>, then is not an high-side MOSFET from that power supply.
But you MUST compare with ALL big coils.

Only inject if you are sure no high-side MOSFET is shorted.
In such case, you can increase voltage, untill heat something...

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: What is considered a high side mosfet? how do i check if they are shorted and what do i compare big coils with

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
High-side MOSFET is part of a buck converter (many on the board).
It is connected between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and the coil of correcponding secondary power supply.
Is paired with a low-side MOSFET, connected to ground.
Be aware, some buck converters use complex ICs, which include the both power MOSFETs.
If you will find the same ohm value to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and a big coil, veru likely corresponding high-side MOSFET is shorted.

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: L74(10,20,30) all had less tha 1ohm to ground removed corresponding u74** and no short on ppbus anymore. <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G</SIGNAL> is shorted which i assume was responsible for the 3 coils. That line just goes to the cpu and some caps could it be a bad cpu?

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
So you had shorted high-side MOSFET.
Injecting voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> could very easy killed CPU.

Low values on CPU coils can be normal, just compare with similar board.
But not too many chances to have a good CPU, after what you did on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Only injected around .7v the board didnt take anything more than that even for the first time. Coils ended up going down to 0 ohms after waiting a while. if cpu isnt dead wat should i do next

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Correction board took around 0.1v at ppbus tried again on coil and took 0.1v and 3amps the only common rail that is shorted between those coils was <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G</SIGNAL>

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
You should compare ohm values with similar board.
Less than 1 ohm is not good sign...

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I'm getting 3.5ohm on those 3 coils on another board. if i do leave the probes on this board, it goes down to 0 or 0.1 theres not much left on that line is there anything left to do?

threads.title: PPBUS Short <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
